plausible_answers.text: the massacre as well as years of turmoil during the Ming-Qing transition

qas.question: Why did the population of Yellow Tiger fall?

context: In the middle of the 17th century, the peasant rebel leader <b4_0>Zhang Xianzhong<b4_0/> (1606–1646) from <b5_0>Yan'an, Shanxi Province,<b5_0/> nicknamed <a0_0><b6_0><b7_0><b9_0>Yellow Tiger<b9_0/><b7_0/><b6_0/><a0_0/>, led his peasant troop from north China to the south, and conquered <a1_0><b10_0>Sichuan<b10_0/><a1_0/>. Upon capturing it, he declared himself emperor of the <a2_0><b8_0><b11_0>Daxi Dynasty<b11_0/><b8_0/><a2_0/> (大西王朝). In response to the resistance from local elites, he massacred a large native population. As a result of <b13_0>the massacre as well as years of turmoil during the Ming-Qing transition<b13_0/>, the population of Sichuan fell sharply, requiring a massive resettlement of people from the neighboring <a3_0><b12_0>Huguang Province<b12_0/><a3_0/> (modern Hubei and Hunan) and other provinces during the Qing dynasty.
